forecast.review: Both forecasters emphasize the overwhelming base rate (no ≥.400 on July 1 in 25+ seasons) and Judge’s clear overperformance indicators (BABIP .481 vs .344 career; xBA ~.362). I agree with those pillars. Forecaster 3’s explicit framing of the remaining sample (roughly six weeks/150–170 AB) is useful and aligns with my earlier estimate. Neither forecaster discussed the ESPN “qualified hitters” nuance, which I think matters for interpreting the resolution source. Overall, their arguments are consistent with mine: Judge’s cushion is real but fragile; regression plus growing denominator make ≥.400 on July 1 unlikely. Their ranges (8% and 15%) bracket my prior 12% well; I don’t see new evidence that materially shifts me off that midpoint.
forecast.rationale: My decomposition remains: (1) Judge’s chance to remain ≥.400 by July 1 as a qualified hitter, plus (2) small mass for anyone else to surge. For Judge: if his forward true BA over the next ~160 AB is ~.35–.365 (in line with xBA ~.362 and likely BABIP regression), the binomial tail for him to hit at or above the required rate to keep his cumulative ≥.400 by July 1 is roughly 10–20%, depending on the exact AB and his current margin above .400. That aligns with Forecaster 3’s intuition and my original calculation. Qualification risk (ESPN leaderboards default to qualified hitters) and modest injury/playing-time risk nudge that downward a bit; on the other hand, Judge’s durability and everyday role keep that penalty small over six weeks. For the field: hitters in the mid-.300s (Freeman ~.375, Ohtani ~.370) would need an extraordinary run (roughly .420–.450 over a large block of ABs) to get to and be ≥.400 on July 1; I assign ~1–2% aggregate. The base rate (zero in 25+ seasons) anchors the forecast below ~20%. The presence of an active ≥.400 candidate anchors it above ~5–8%. Net: I remain near the middle of the other forecasters’ range and keep my prior estimate.
